text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised text for IRM 5.11.3, Jeopardy Levy without a Jeopardy Assessment.
IRM 5.11.3.1 is revised to include internal controls information.
) IRM
) is revised to clarify when CAP rights are provided. (
) IRM
) is revised to delete obsolete note. The delegation of authority to approve jeopardy levies is with Division Counsel (SB/SE). (
) IRM
is revised to clarify that written Counsel approval is required in all of the situations (
) Editorial changes made throughout.
This IRM supersedes IRM 5.11.3 dated April 03,
This material is used by SB/SE revenue officers and collection
Table of Contents
Levy without a Jeopardy Assessment

) Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section describes the and procedures for preparation of a jeopardy levy. Speciﬁcally, the IRM and discusses: a. the required conditions for jeopardy levy b. obtaining approval for a jeopardy levy c. issuing notice to the taxpayer after the levy d. the taxpayer’s appeal rights after notice is provided (
) Audience: This IRM is designed for use by revenue officers, collection advisors, and their managers. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy. Collection Policy is an under Small Business/Sell-Employed Division (SBSE), Collection. (
) Program Owner: SBSE Collection Policy, Enforcement. (
) Primary Stakeholders: SBSE revenue officers and collection advisors. (
) Program Goals: Enforcement is a necessary component of a voluntary sessment system, see IRM
, Policy Statement

While we will actively assist taxpayers to comply, we will also take appropriate actions when warranted to resolve the delinquency. Levies are an enforcement tool. By following the procedures in this IRM, revenue officers be able to identify jeopardy levy situations, and properly prepare, issue, address appeals of jeopardy levies. (
) Normally, the notices and waiting periods described in IRM
, Required Notices must be issued before property may be levied. However, collection is in jeopardy, property may be levied sooner. (
) Authorities relating to this section include: • IRC
- Notice and demand for tax • IRC
- Notice and opportunity for hearing before levy • IRC
- Levy and distraint • IRC
- Surrender of property subject to levy • IRC
- Review of jeopardy levy or assessment procedures • Treasury Regulations §
- Levy and distraint • Treasury Regulations §
- Surrender of property subject levy • Treasury Regulations §
- Surrender of property subject levy in the case of life insurance and endowment contracts • IRM
, Policy Statement
, Enforcement is a necessary component of a voluntary assessment system • IRM
, Policy Statement
, Jeopardy assessments to used sparingly and assessment to be reasonable in amount • IRM

Notice of (
) Managers of employees who issue levies are responsible for ensuring these procedures are followed and employee actions are timely and accurate. (
) Revenue officers and collection advisors are responsible for following the cedures in this IRM. (
) Integrated Collection System (ICS) is used by ﬁeld revenue officers as a method for generating levy documents that are issued to third party levy sources. (
) The Collection Activity Reports (CAR) report number

records the number of levies issued. Total Levies are the sum of Field, SB/SE ACS and & I ACS (monthly and cumulative). The data sources are the ACS Customer Service Activity Reports (CSAR) - Monthly Support Site Report (ACS and ICS (Field Levies). See IRM
, Levy and Seizure Report (Report Symbol NO-

). The IRS has determined that levy data may be made available as national statistics, provided that such data will never be used to evaluate any employee or to suggest or impose production quotas or goals. See IRM
, Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System, of Section
Statistics. (
) Levy program numbers are published yearly in the IRS Data Book, Enforce- ment: Collections, Penalties & Criminal Investigation, in Table
at https:// www.irs.gov/uac/enforcement-collections-penalties-criminal-investigation (
) Targeted program reviews are periodically performed by Collection Policy to determine whether IRM guidance requires clariﬁcation or revision. (
) Management will ensure program effectiveness through managers’ case reviews, operational reviews conducted by the territory, Area, and Field tion Director, and NQRS reviews. (
) National Quality Review System (NQRS), attribute
, Managerial for Enforcement provides independent collection review information from management may draw inferences regarding overall case quality for this attribute. See IRM
, Embedded Quality Administrative Guidelines. (
) Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS), Collection managers use attribute
, Appropriate Enforcement Tools, and attribute
, Taxpayer Rights to complete all case reviews for revenue officers. (
) Jeopardy notices of levy must be approved by managers and Division Counsel. See IRM
, Delegation Order
(Rev-
), Levy on Property the Hands of a Third Party (not to include Levy Form
) Certain manual refunds must be approved by managers. See IRM
, Delegation Order
(Rev.
), Credits and Refunds. (
) Programming safeguards are built into the ICS system to prevent a levy being generated on a module where the required notices have not been issued.
Managers of employees who issue levies are responsible for ensuring these procedures are followed and employee actions are timely and accurate.
Jeopardy Levy without a Jeopardy Assessment
Terms and acronyms associated with the ﬁeld levy program include:

Word Deﬁnition Automated Levy Automated levies are levies issued through the Automated Levy Programs. These levies are transmitted electronically. The proceeds are also received elec- tronically. Manual Levy A manual ICS levy is a paper levy that is manually prepared and issued by an RO. Paper levy Either a manual or systemic levy on Form 668-A(C)(DO), Form 668-W(C) (DO), or Form 668- W(ICS) that is prepared and issued by an RO. Systemic Levy ICS systemic levies are initiated by ROs resulting in levy prepara- tion and issuance by the ICS system.
Note: ACS methods of levy issuances are discussed in IRM 5.19.4.3.10(1), Levy Types.
See Exhibit
for list of Acronyms. The ICS User Guide, Chapter

- Levy details all the functions necessary maintain levy sources, issue levies and ﬁnal demands, and close or release levies. See http://icsweb.web.irs.gov/Docs/HTML/user_guide.htm. The National Levy Source Look-Up web page provides up-to-date levy name and address information. See pages/nl
xhtml. The M

B/SE, Enforcement web page provides access to various and job aids related to the levy program. Seehttp://mysbse.web.irs.gov/ Collection/toolsprocesses/Enforcement/default.aspx. The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) links to listing of those rights that existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
broad categories. See https://www.irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights. For additional information see IRM
, Policy Statement

Generally, if collection is in jeopardy, there is a jeopardy or termination assess

ment. Then there is an immediate notice and demand which is followed by a jeopardy levy. Sometimes, however, there may already be an assessment before jeopardy is known and in some of those cases, collection under regular procedures may have begun before the jeopardy is known.

In every situation where a jeopardy levy occurs without a jeopardy or termi- nation assessment, the Service has already assessed the tax liability through normal procedures. If collection is not in jeopardy, a quick assessment or prompt assessment is insufficient to support a levy immediately after issuing notice and demand. However, if collection is in jeopardy, the jeopardy situation may support an immediate levy after personal service, if practical, of the notice and demand (Form
Levy without a Jeopardy Assessment 5.11.3 page

There may be a prompt assessment on a voluntarily ﬁled return. Then, the taxpayer starts moving property to hide it, a revenue officer may make a jeopardy levy if collection is in jeopardy, after securing the required approvals outlined in IRM
, Getting Approval. Property may be levied, even though the usual waiting periods after notices have not passed.
may be levied, even though the usual waiting periods after notices not passed. Example: If the Service makes a quick assessment to recover refunds resulting from a false Form
–OID, Original Issue Discount ﬁling, a officer may make a jeopardy levy if collection is in jeopardy, after securing the required approvals outlined in IRM
, Getting Approval. (
) A taxpayer must be offered IRC
appeal rights when: • The notice and demand described in IRC
for an assessment not been issued or the
-day waiting period arising after the of that notice has not expired; or • A notice of intent to levy described in IRC
) specifying tax and tax period has not been issued for the property subject to or the waiting period described in IRC
) has not expired. IRM
), Required Notices. (
) A taxpayer must be offered Collection Due Process (CDP) rights pursuant IRC
(f) within a reasonable period of time after the levy when the taxpayer has not been offered a hearing previously for the taxable period the type of tax subject to the levy. (
) A taxpayer will be offered an appeal under the Collection Appeals Program (CAP) when the taxpayer is not entitled to either CDP appeal rights or
appeal rights, and when the taxpayer who is entitled to such rights declined them. (

) Situations in which a taxpayer may request an appeal under CAP can arise the following situations in which the Service is generally prohibited from levying, but for which an exception for jeopardy levy has been provided: • On the appearance date of a summons, • While an installment agreement is pending or active, • For

days following the date of termination of an installment agreement and during an appeal of the termination, • During the period a rejected installment agreement can be appealed is being appealed, • During the period an offer in compromise is pending, or • During the period a rejected offer in compromise can be appealed or being appealed. (
) Hereafter, any reference to jeopardy levy in this section shall refer only to jeopardy levy without a jeopardy or termination assessment unless noted. (
) A jeopardy levy requires a condition that would have allowed a jeopardy as- sessment. Internal Revenue Manual

) If the collection of an assessed tax is in jeopardy, prepare either a written report or a narrative Integrated Collection System (ICS) history entry for the territory manager requesting approval to issue a jeopardy levy. Include the same information that is needed for a jeopardy assessment. See IRM
, Jeopardy, Termination, Quick and Prompt Assessments. Send the request through the group manager. (

) The managerial approval process may be accomplished by having the group manager and territory manager access ICS and document their approval history entry. Electronic signature by the approving official is an acceptable method of written approval. When written or electronic approval is secured, a copy of the approval must be kept in the ﬁle and the RO will document the history. (
) Per IRC
, Chief Counsel must approve in writing a jeopardy levy before is made. See IRM
) and (

When the jeopardy levy is to be issued to a third party who is in possession of the taxpayer’s property or property rights, prepare Letter

when warranted to include with the notice of levy. Additional time may be warranted based on the unique factors of each case. This letter asks the party in receipt of the levy to delay sending payment for

days because the taxpayer is entitled to certain appeal rights but warns not to let the taxpayer have the funds that have been attached during that period. This allows time to see if the taxpayer appeals. If the taxpayer successfully appeals, the levy may be released rather than issuing a manual refund.

When the jeopardy levy is to be issued to a third party who is in possession of the taxpayer’s property or property rights, prepare Letter 2438 when warranted to include with the notice of levy. Additional time may be warranted based on the unique factors of each case. This letter asks the party in receipt of the levy to delay sending payment for 45 days because the taxpayer is entitled to certain appeal rights but warns not to let the taxpayer have the funds that have been attached during that period. This allows time to see if the taxpayer appeals. If the taxpayer successfully appeals, the levy may be released rather than issuing a manual refund.

) The issue on review under IRC

is whether the jeopardy levy is reason- able under the circumstances (collection is truly in jeopardy). If Appeals sustains the jeopardy levy, the taxpayer may obtain judicial review of the jeopardy levy. The decision of the court regarding reasonableness may not appealed to a higher court. Note: Generally, district courts have exclusive jurisdiction over IRC
; if any of the liabilities on the jeopardy levy were in a statutory notice of ciency that was timely petitioned before the making of the jeopardy levy, taxpayer may, alternatively, obtain IRC
review of all periods in the jeopardy levy by the Tax Court in an expedited procedure that only the reasonableness of the levy. See Tax Court Rule
